body:
Hi AugierLe42e,

thanks for your contribution. :)

New features should be discussed on the developer mailing list. See: http://groovy-lang.org/mailing-lists.html on how to subscribe.

Thanks!
Sure ! Of course ! Thank you, I'm writing it.
You might want to use java.beans.Introspector.decapitalize which handles some special cases like getZ and getURL. Also we probably need to handle primitive boolean methods of the form isPropName().

It is probably also worth checking for no parameters for getters (we don't normally consider indexed properties) and likewise exactly one parameter only for setters. I am a little fuzzy also whether we should include read-only or write-only properties (i.e. only a getter or only a setter) - I'll have to think about that one a bit more. But being more restrictive as you currently are is the safer of the two options for now.

Also, the setters could be checked for void return type. And if we do eventually support read-only getters, we need to rule out some things Groovy adds like getMetaClass and getDeclaringClass and we probably don't want getClass from Java either.
@PascalSchumacher @paulk-asert Sure, thanks for the comments and ideas. Will take up this one and update the PR soon :)
@PascalSchumacher @paulk-asert Done! Kindly have a look at it and let me know, if any more changes is needed from my side!

Merged: https://github.com/apache/incubator-groovy/commit/d37a7dcc82c2dd392fd1ac2eea7250acced1b3de https://github.com/apache/incubator-groovy/commit/0e65abcdf8f23f9d156fccc616619548b528b9e8

Thanks!
Thanks

Merged: https://github.com/apache/incubator-groovy/commit/40dd9b30879fe057626bedec64a824fde114e8d8

Thanks :+1: 

Could you please close this pull request? I can not do it using the github gui because this is a read only mirror.

Thanks!

@antoaravinth thanks for the update! :)

It looks like your pull request is still missing these requirements from Paul:

"It is probably also worth checking for no parameters for getters (we don't normally consider indexed properties) and likewise exactly one parameter only for setters."

"Also, the setters could be checked for void return type."
Merged, thanks!

@PascalSchumacher Sorry didn't check it, actually let me know my understanding is correct:
1. Check getters doesn't have any params.
2. Check set has always void as return type. 

These two changes needs to be added right?
@antoaravinth Yes, your understanding is correct.
Looks good as far as I can tell. :+1:
@PascalSchumacher Now its done! :) Let me know if anything is needed from my end.

HI @roranade , good catch, thanks! I've made the change and auto-formatted that line.

Just on the formatting...

Re: `groovy.ui.GroovyMain` - I've tried to make the formatting similar to what's already there. Intellij doesn't like the current formatting (in `GroovyMain`), so I've left it as is (3 space tab indents, strange indenting in the `#buildOptions()` code).

Very nice! It might also be nice to enable the functionality via the ant tasks:

```
org.codehaus.groovy.ant.Groovy
org.codehaus.groovy.ant.Groovyc
```

Have a look at how the stacktrace flag is handled (and possibly how the verbose flag is passed on for joint options in groovyc - might be relevant to do this too - I haven't thought through the joint scenario fully yet).

The only other comment I have is that the patch currently doesn't handle some tricky cases where setting the access might be appropriate, e.g. first parameter "this$0" for an inner class should probably be marked synthetic/implicit and possibly a couple of spots within enums too. But so long as not handling such cases doesn't cause a problem, we can probably endeavor to tweak the behavior to be smarter down the track. Maybe add a TODO comment in your patch for now, e.g. "// TODO handle synthetic/implicit?" just before the call to visitParameter.

Forgot to mention the relevant place for doco changes (which would be nice too):
src/spec/doc/tools-groovyc.adoc (two places, groovyc commandline and groovyc ant task)
src/spec/doc/groovy-ant-task.adoc

Thanks @paulk-asert , I didn't even think of ant tasks or the doco. I'll make those changes later today.

**RE: Access Settings** - I didn't understand what the difference was between synthetic/implicit(/???), so I just left them as `0` for now. I could just add a `todo`, but I don't mind doing it properly either. I'll reverse engineer/asm some JDK8 classes, to see how the value changes for enums and inner classes. If you can point me to any documentation, that'd be a great help too!

Don't know whether this will help:
http://docs.oracle.com/javase/tutorial/displayCode.html?code=http://docs.oracle.com/javase/tutorial/reflect/member/example/MethodParameterSpy.java

See the Java tutorial for details:
http://docs.oracle.com/javase/tutorial/reflect/member/methodparameterreflection.html

But as you may or may not know, Groovy's enums are a bit different from Java's enums under the covers, so there might not be an exact one-to-one correspondence.
For bonus marks, you'd also update the doco on the groovy commandline itself but we haven't migrated that across to the new documentation yet.

Thanks @paulk-asert , that's perfect. Reading up on http://docs.oracle.com/javase/tutorial/reflect/member/methodparameterreflection.html#implcit_and_synthetic now.

Will update groovysh (`org.codehaus.groovy.tools.shell.Main`), with documentation later.

---

Just some other thoughts (I'll leave this for another day):

1) Does gradle's [groovy plugin](http://gradle.org/docs/current/userguide/groovy_plugin.html) support compiler args? (I could only enable `-parameters` by using a [configurationScript](http://gradle.org/docs/current/dsl/org.gradle.api.tasks.compile.GroovyCompileOptions.html#org.gradle.api.tasks.compile.GroovyCompileOptions:configurationScript)).

i.e. I should be able to do this...

```
compileGroovy {
    groovyOptions.compilerArgs << '-parameters'
}
```

2) Update [Groovy Eclipse Maven plugin](https://github.com/groovy/groovy-eclipse/) to support `-parameters` arg?
3) Intellij > 'Groovy Compiler' settings (<kbd>Ctrl</kbd>+<kbd>Alt</kbd>+<kbd>S</kbd>) doesn't support compiler args?

OK, now a placeholder doco for groovy commandline:

```
src/spec/doc/tools-groovy.adoc
```

We may move that around or rename it yet.

Yep, groovysh and groovyConsole would be lower priority but should be handled eventually. And yes, we'd need to percolate it out to other tools eventually but not relevant for this PR for sure. Don't know a better Gradle option off the top of my head.

**Notes**

I tried using the ASMifier, to decompile all (as many) variations of parameter accessors (e.g. inner classes, implicit constructors, enums) as I could. The only time I got a value other than `0`, was for enums, which had `ACC_SYNTHETIC` on their method parameters. Saying that, the parameters still work using `0` for an enum.

e.g. (`groovyConsole -pa`)

``` Groovy
class Foobar {
    enum Alpha { AAA, BBB}
    def run(String firstParam, int secondParam){}
}

def showPaNames = { clazz, methName -> 
    clazz.methods.find{it.name==methName}.parameters.collect{it.name}
}
println showPaNames(Foobar, 'run')
println showPaNames(Foobar.Alpha, 'valueOf')
```

**Gives...**

``` Groovy
[firstParam, secondParam]
[name] // <- should be two params???
```

Also, groovyConsole's argument handling was "manual", so I updated it to use the `CliBuilder`.

**Done**
- Add to groovy
- Add to groovyc
- Add to groovysh
- Add to groovyConsole
- Change system property config
- Comment TODO on ASM accessor

**Backlog**
- Add to ant tasks
- Update documentation
- Test
Looks fine to me, but I never worked on groovydoc. @paulk-asert what do you think?
@paulk-asert What do you think? Is this ready to merge?
Thanks!

Looks good from what I can see. Given that we don't have much "integration test" coverage for using our tools from the commandline, I just wanted to be a little cautious and manually double check all the changes. Also, I wondered whether the @SuppressWarnings("static-access") is related to the "synchronized" or not. If yes, we should be able to delete it. I might have time for those checks next week but happy for someone else to quickly cast their eyes over it and check that nothing changed and if that's the case, we should be good to go.

I think it is very close. There are little things which I'd probably tweak, e.g.:
setOrGet.contains("is") would match "history", so startsWith would be better.
Thanks!

Nice work! One thing I didn't spot earlier is that the comment header at the top of our source files has changed very slightly to conform with Apache guidelines. You should find the new version on any of the recent source files. We need to tweak URLGetBytesTest.groovy to use the latest version. Thanks.
Got it, updated the license to match the one I found in ./src/main/org/codehaus/groovy/ast/tools/BeanUtils.java
Applied, thanks!
Applied, thanks!

A trick we use to be able to add such tests into the build is to use `notYetImplemented` which is an available method in your test class, e.g. add the following as the first line of your test:

```
if (notYetImplemented()) return
```

Also, you might like to update the comment header from one of the other recent Groovy source files - we are getting ready to release under Apache guidelines and have tweaked the wording slightly.
Thanks Paul, I've updated the license in the header and added the `notYetImplemented()` call to the (otherwise failing) method.

I am not sure whether you have received all the answers you need to progress or whether you have some new ideas but if you want to leave this PR open, you might like to fix up the compilation error (one too many closing braces).
:+1: Thanks!

@paulk-asert I guess it's functionally equivalent, but even easier/more obvious to annotate the test method with @NotYetImplemented (http://docs.groovy-lang.org/latest/html/gapi/groovy/transform/NotYetImplemented.html)?

@nickgrealy Thanks for the great work so far. :)

Could you also rebase to latest master, because the merge of https://github.com/apache/incubator-groovy/pull/11 caused some conflicts with your pull request? Thanks!

Oh ! Right ! Well, yes, I want to to finish this PR. What do you need to merge it ? Unit tests ?
I suppose I'll need:
- add a `Closure` with `leftShift` and verify it is in the list,
- call without any argument and check the `Closure` has been called,
- call with multiple arguments and check the `Closure` has been called with the correct argument.

Do you need any thing else ?

Sorry I've not been active on this recently. I'm busy with the exams comming and my Android project to finish.
Where can I see the compilation errors ?
I like that, I've pushed the modified version.

Yep, that's good too. I tend to always use the annotation version with my JUnit 4 tests but often use the old version with my JUnit 3 style tests - but maybe that's just out of habit. Using the annotation is good in that case too.
http://ci.groovy-lang.org/viewLog.html?buildId=22697&tab=buildResultsDiv&buildTypeId=Groovy_Jdk6Build (Login as Guest)
@PascalSchumacher , sure thing.
And a squash might be good too.
Will do.
Thanks!
Thanks for your work John.

Thanks for your efforts in creating the PR. I have merged #21, so I'll close this one - but if you feel you need further changes, feel free to create another PR based on the current master. Thanks again.
Hi Paul, thanks for looking at this.  I'll take a look at using a meta-annotation for this and check in on the mailing list if I have any problems.  Cheers.
It seems to be okay. I added another testcase but perhaps I didn't quite catch the case you were after?
Thanks!
My pleasure.

Thanks for spotting the anomaly with RGM#splitEachLine. I created an issue here:
https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/GROOVY-7440
And ended up with a slightly different solution:
https://github.com/apache/incubator-groovy/commit/5b521788
Thanks! :+1:
Thanks! :+1:
Ok, this look finished to me. Ready for review.

Actually, I do have a concern about this PR. I'd like to find a way to constraint parameters of the closure from what the user would pass to the constructor. Something like this:

```
Event event = new Event(variable1: int, variable2: String)
```

so variables would be directly available when declaring an anonymous closure:

```
event << { 
    int var = variable1
    variable2.each{ print it }
}
```

Would it be possible ?
Greeting to GR8Conf EU 2015. :)
Line endings should be unmodified now
Thanks! :+1:
My pleasure :+1:
Thanks! :+1:
Thank you! Thanks for helping me demonstrate how to contribute to Groovy :D
Great first commit! Now keep them coming!
Did you get a chance to squash? Are you finished for now wrt the backlog you mentioned?

So, quick update. Finally managed to make some time to rebase and squash the code.

Since then, I implemented the ant groovy tasks (just testing atm) and added everything to the documentation.

1) @paulk-asert - I did notice there was a bug in the following doco file:
https://raw.githubusercontent.com/apache/incubator-groovy/master/src/spec/doc/tools-groovyc.adoc
`|-indy|--indy|Enables invokedynamic support. Requires Java 7+|groovyc --indy Person.groovy`
should be:
`| -indy | --indy | Enables invokedynamic support. Requires Java 7+ | groovy --indy Person.groovy`
(the `7+|` is breaking the following docs in the table Also, does this needs to be updated in https://raw.githubusercontent.com/apache/incubator-groovy/master/src/spec/doc/tools-groovy.adoc ?).
(I've made the change to my branch, but you might want to fix it for the upcoming release?)

2) Also, I wanted to document the `groovy.parameters` system property, but am not sure where it belongs. Any ideas?
@blackdrag Is this good to merge?
@blackdrag Is the good to merge?

Excellent work! The rebase/squash seems a little weird? Squashed down to 112 commits? Thanks for spotting the doco issues - yep, I will fix up manually in the 2_4_X branch. I'll check on where groovy.parameters doco should go.

Yeh, it was my first rebase/squash... so I'm not sure it did what it was supposed to(??).

Ant tasks look good, except for one (existing?) issue that I'm looking at. [Joint compilation](http://www.groovy-lang.org/groovyc.html#ThegroovycAntTask-JointCompilation) (i.e. integrated java compilation) is NOT using/passing on the `-parameters` flag (for Java classes only).

``` xml
<groovyc srcdir="src" destdir="out" parameters="true">
    <javac source="1.8" target="1.8" debug="on" >
        <compilerarg value="-parameters"/>
    </javac>
</groovyc>
```

https://github.com/nickgrealy/incubator-groovy/blob/master/subprojects/groovy-ant/src/main/java/org/codehaus/groovy/ant/Groovyc.java#L968-979
you did "git rebase master"?

After fetching `upstream` (i.e. -> `apache/incubator-groovy`), I used `git rebase -i HEAD~8`, where 8 was my last 8 commits (obviously this isn't correct). I'll give `git rebase master` a go this evening.
hmmm, I couldn't see the problem you mentioned in tools-groovyc.adoc, perhaps something weird happened with your rebase attempt? Unless I am missing something.

@paulk-asert , take a look at the [latest docs for the `master` branch](http://ci.groovy-lang.org/repository/download/Groovy_Jdk7Build/23592:id/target/distributions/apache-groovy-docs-2.5.0-SNAPSHOT.zip%21/groovy-2.5.0-SNAPSHOT/html/documentation/index.html#section-groovyc-compiler), on the CI server ([same for the 2.4.4 Branch](http://ci.groovy-lang.org/repository/download/Groovy_Jdk7Build/23607:id/target/distributions/apache-groovy-docs-2.4.4-SNAPSHOT.zip%21/groovy-2.4.4-SNAPSHOT/html/documentation/index.html#section-groovyc-compiler)).

Notice how the groovyc table is truncated after the `--basescript` parameter? There should be a few more parameters, which aren't showing up because of the `--indy` parameter.
Ah, my bad - was looking in tools-groovy.adoc not tools-groovyc.adoc. I see the problem now. Thanks.
fixed and you should get that change if you rebase again (sorry)
If the rebase is too hard, you could create a diff of just your changes, close this PR, create a fresh branch from master and apply the diff and make that into a PR.

Awesome, thanks for fixing the docs. Not a problem, I've almost nailed down the ant java compiler thing. Will have another go at rebasing -> squashing after that. Will stick with this pull request for now. :)
Thanks! :+1:

Hi Keegan,

thanks for the pull request. :)

It would be nice if you could squash the commits. Let know if this is to much bother, then I will do it for you.

Thanks!

Sorry, I've got a bad habit of merging instead of rebasing.  Would you like these squashed as "removed JavaDoc erroneously stating UTF-16 BOM will be written" and "document UTF-16 BOM writing"?  Or just 1 commit?
Thanks! Two commits are perfect. :+1:
Thanks! :)
Thanks! Great pull request. :+1:

Hi @paulk-asert , I've done a `git fetch upstream` and a `git rebase -i upstream/master`, which has (hopefully) squashed my changes. Please have a look when you get a minute. I think it's all "good to go".

It still looks a little weird to me. I would be expecting just a small number of commits - possibly just one if you squashed completely. I'll see if anyone else has some git advise on how to correct. Me, I'd do old school close and re-open at this point.

I have seen this happen before when I squash the commits on my local branch and push my local branch to remote repository without `force pushing` it.

There are a few ways this can be corrected. One of them is to --

`git reset --hard <shaOfLastest upstream/master commit>`
`git cherry-pick <squashed commit's sha>` -- (Assuming there is only 1 final squashed commit)
`git push -f origin master` -- A force push to forked master branch

Also, as Paul said, closing this branch/PR and opening a new branch and cherry-picking the commits on the new branch may probably be cleaner (albeit that would not be much different from `git reset --hard` in this case)

Thanks, I'll give the cherry picking a go, and fall back to the diff if I'm still having troubles. 

I'm a bit of a newb to git, so just for next time, should I be working in a branch, within my fork? I was simply working off my master...
IMO, unless you are working on multiple features at once, having just master is probably fine but in general, yes I do think its better to create a branch to work on.
Looks great! Nice work!
Cool cool cool. Just wanted to say thanks Paul, for the help and patience. What's the next step from here? Is there anything else I can do? (I'm conscious that time equals more rebasing...)
Applied. Glad you persisted with your efforts. A neat feature to have!
